instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.BKLT_SCL: What is BKLT_SCL? BKLT_SCL is an I2C signal clock line between the LED driver that creates the LCD backlight power rail that powers the backlight in the screen and the screen. The screen needs to speak to the LED driver on this line before backlight voltage will be created..
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.BKLT_SD: What is BKLT_SD? BKLT_SD is a pin of the LED driver that goes to the voltage divider that feeds the gate of the transistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H and the backlight circuit. The LED driver will short this pin to ground when backlight circuit is ready to turn on. Prerequisites are 1) it is told to turn on via enable signal, the screen has communicated with the LED driver 2) current sensing circuit is working 3) does not detect an over-current situation such as the backlight power rail being shorted to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
Board has liquid damage, I have replaced the following from a donor board: <TRANSISTOR>Q8401</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR>
New chips piurchased and replaced already: <CHIP>U8510</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R8402</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C8411</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R8433</RESISTOR>.
I have 0v on <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_FET_DRV</SIGNAL>. I cannot seem to track down why there is no backlight. I have ordered some extra LP8548B1SQ chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at both pins of <DIODE>D8410</DIODE>; w/ and w/o LCD connected.
Do you get image for sure?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
Yes, I see the apple logo come up and it wants to connect to wifi.
Pin 1 is .838, pin 2 is 1.174.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
Did you test with known good LCD assembly?

Post <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> voltages.
Do you get <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL>?

Be sure all <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>-53 are good, as their traces too.
Check voltage and diode mode at SCL/SDA lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 98595, member: 682"]
Did you test with known good LCD assembly?
[/QUOTE]
Yes, assembly screen is good.
<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> I get nothing.
<RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>-53 all look good. 
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> is at 5.1v, SDA is also the same voltage.
<TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> pin 1= .045,  pin 3=12.27, pin 4= 12.58

My reference only: Ticket # REF1125

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R8442</RESISTOR> is good?
Missing <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> too?

<CHIP>U8400</CHIP> gets correct VDDA/D?
Check all surrounding components and traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> only has .800. I noticed <CHIP>U7270</CHIP> had corrosion around it so I replaced 3 caps: <CAPACITOR>C7273</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7273</CAPACITOR>, CD7A2, and reflowed <CHIP>U7270</CHIP>. I noticed the processor started getting hot so I hooked it up to the external display and I am getting picture now. The spinning globe was cutting in and out at first, may be a bad USB-C connection but I am happy for getting video now. 

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 98601, member: 682"]
<RESISTOR>R8442</RESISTOR> is good?
Missing <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> too?
[/QUOTE]
No voltage for <RESISTOR>R8442</RESISTOR>.
Yes <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> is missing.
<CHIP>U8400</CHIP> VDDA/D both get 5v.
<RESISTOR>R8433</RESISTOR> Pin 2 still has no voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
Forget <RESISTOR>R8433</RESISTOR>; backlight is not even enabled yet.

Do you get 5V at pin 45 of J8500?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 98797, member: 682"]
Do you get 5V at pin 45 of J8500?
[/QUOTE]
Yes I do, hooked it up to the built in screen and I also have picture there, but no backlight.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
If there is image, LCD is correctly detected.
So CPU should enable backlight.
Unless there is some problem on backlight circuytry and <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> sned back to CPU an error through I2C bus.
You've mentioned that changed many componentes there.
May have corroded trace, bad solder, knocked off component.

Just in case, try SMC reset.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message: I do have 3.2v on <CHIP>U8510</CHIP> pin 2. I had worked on this some. Going to try and reseat this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
That pin controls power to LCD matrix; previous stept, before enabling backlight.
Backlight enable signal comes directly from CPU.

Did you try SMC reset?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message: I will try that now but after further visual inspection <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> test point the traces on both sides seem to be corroded so bad that they are missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message: Thats what it was! Ran the jumper from one side of the trace to the other. Thank you so much!!
